description: From French myriade, from Late Latin myriadem (accusative of myrias), from Ancient Greek μυριάς (muriás, “number of 10,000”), from μυρίος (muríos, “numberless, countless, infinite”).

entries.meaning: (modifying a singular noun) Multifaceted, having innumerable elements [from 18th c.]
examples: one night he would be singing at the barred window and yelling down out of the soft myriad darkness of a May night; the next night he would be gone [...].

entries.meaning: (modifying a plural noun) Great in number; innumerable, multitudinous [from 18th c.]
A countless number or multitude (of specified things) [from 16th c.]
examples: Earth hosts a myriad of animals.
